utterances: Bona Benjamin, thank you very much for your time today.
And, Richard Knox, thank you too.
The junkie comes up next as we talk about Chris Christie.
This is NPR News.
From NPR News, this is DAY TO DAY, with news about how you may watch television in the near future.
At the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas today, Comcast - that's the big cable TV company - Comcast announced it wants to let you download movies and TV shows.
MARKETPLACE's Nancy Marshall-Genzer is here.
And Nancy, other companies are doing this, or they want to at least.
Why is it a big deal that Comcast announced this today?
Well, Madeleine, actually they had two announcements.
One is they announced there is a new Web site.
It's going to be free, called Fancast.com, available to anybody, and you will be able to use that to download TV shows and some movies.
But the bigger news is some new technology called wideband.
And that you'll have to pay for, but it could be worth it because Comcast says you can download a two-and-a-half-hour movie in less than four minutes rather than the usual six hours.
And yes, this will make Comcast more competitive.
One analyst I talked to, Michael Greene(ph) of JupiterResearch, says at this point, Comcast definitely has an advantage over its competitors.
Cable operators already (unintelligible) in people's homes, and having the largest content libraries seem to have a leading position, but it's really too soon to tell.
Now, Nancy, what about the competition?
There have been reports that Apple might be doing the same thing, rolling out its own video rental service?
That's right.
And Comcast will compete with Apple in the sense that Apple's not already in everybody's - Comcast is not in everybody's home.
Apple's new service will be available to anyone who has a computer with broadband.
And so our analyst, Greene, says don't count Apple out yet.
I think reading is cool again, and it could be attributed to Harry Potter, but it's cool because there are more books to be offered that show children of color, that have children of color.

Dodson's publication is recommending several, including Marilyn Nelson's ""A Wreath for Emmett Till,"" Brenda Woods' ""Emako Blue"" and Walter Mosley's ""47."" She says there are several ways parents could help get their children more involved in reading, including helping them to create reading clubs or taking them to book-related events at stores.
The best way, Dodson says, is to show your children that you value books by letting them see you read.
Allison Keyes, NPR News, New York.
To see more of the Black Issues Book Review recommendations, visit our Web site at npr.org.
This is NPR News.
Like many of us, writer Bill Barich had an image of the perfect Irish pub: a smiling barman, witty conversation, turf in the fireplace - a comfortable, unpretentious place.
It had to be real.
He'd seen it in the movies.

Then he moved to Dublin and started a search, first in his neighborhood, across the city and the countryside to learn that the traditional Irish pub of his imagination is now a product of corporate marketeers who establish reproductions of Irish pubs in airports and hotels around the world at just about the same rate as the real thing is vanishing.
So what is it that makes a great pub?
Give us a call: 800-989-8255.
Email us: talk@npr.org.
And you can join the conversation on our Web site.
That's at npr.org.
Just click on TALK OF THE NATION.
Bill Barich joins us now from the studios of NPR West.
His new book is ""A Pint of Plain: Tradition, Change, and the Fate of the Irish Pub."" Thanks so much for coming in.
Well, you're quite welcome, Neal.
And from your description, there are some things that a pub has to have to be terrific, and some things it should definitely not have.
Well, you know, I think the kind of romantic image I had, it still obtains, in many ways.
And there are - they're getting to be a bit like needles in the haystack.
But if you look hard enough, you find that quintessential Irish pub here and there.
And there are certain things that it requires to meet that standard, which is to say you should not be confronted by a bevy of flat-screen TVs showing rugby, soccer, ""American Idol,"" even.
You should not have piped-in music.
You should not have barmen and barwomen who don't know how to pour a proper pint.

It should be a place that feels like an extension of home, and not quite work and not quite home - a third place, as a certain sociologist has put it, that encourages friendships that would not occur under normal circumstances.
A good pub is a real democracy, where you'll walk in and you'll find a banker talking to a plumber about horse racing or, you know, a politician talking to a - whatever, a farmer about local issues.
So all of those things go into constituting a really first-rate pub.
And there is a quality that you refer to in the book - and it's not your word.
It's an Irish word: craic.
Craic, indeed, yeah, spelled C-R-A-I-C, which is a funny sort of story.
It's a totally made-up word.
The media created it so that there'd be no confusion with crack cocaine.
C-R-A-C-K is the way it's said.
And it just - it applies to the kind of fun - particularly the kind of fun that can be had in pubs, and it involves conversation, drink and sometimes music.
And music that does not come necessarily from a playlist.
That's right, yeah.
Made by actual human beings.
And, you know, if you run into a good pub where a session is going on, it absolutely is magic.
And craic tends to - if you go to a small town, there may be - there's always an overabundance of pubs.
There would be, you know, 10 in a village of 300 or 400 people.
And the craic moves by random and by mysterious ways from one to the other.
And you'll notice that people will begin to gravitate toward that spot.
One sociologist called it - it's almost like a performance art.
It's improvised.
It begins, and then it ends without any signal from anybody.
It just occurs.
It just occurs.
I just wonder, these days, are people getting text messages saying the craic's on at Shannon's tonight?
I'm sure they are.
Absolutely.
Would that be one of the qualities of a good pub, that maybe cell phones have to be turned off?
Well, you know, people are very polite, still, in Ireland.
And you find that in pubs.
You know, if you come in and you order a pint and you go sit at a table, the barman or the barwoman will bring you the pint.
They'll find you, no matter where you are in the pub.

And in a good pub, anybody who's using a cell phone will immediately step outside if they get a call, so as not to - you won't find that horrible thing that you find, may I say, here in America, you know, where someone is in the seat next to you on the plane and, you know, talking, you know, about Aunt Molly and her problems.
You know?
You just don't get that.
As people can probably tell from your accent, you're not originally from Ireland.
You moved there fairly recently.
I did, yes.
Now, I was on holiday in London, and I met a woman from Dublin and basically, I followed her home and had the good luck for everything to work out.
So I've been there for a while now.
And as you - here's an email, by the way, we got from Stan in Jacksonville, Florida.
What makes a good Irish pub?
He rhetorically asks himself.
Good craic.
So there you have it.
(Soundbite of laughter)
(unintelligible)
But as you started this search for - you thought it would be pretty easy - I mean, there's so many pubs in Dublin, that finding a good local wouldn't be that hard.
Well, yeah.
I think roughly 12,000 in the entire country.
And in my neighborhood, which is really very small, there were eight within, oh, 400 or 500 yards of the house.
So I thought: It's a simple matter.
I'll just, you know, drop in here and drop in there, which I did.
And either there would be the pipe music, or there would be a semblance of an American sports bar or, in one case, a place that turned into a singles bar on Saturday night.
And you'd walk by on a summer evening, which in Dublin is never very warm, and you would find young women dressed in these - as though there were in a beach town, sort of shivering outside.
And I thought, I don't want to see Malibu here.
You know?
This is not right.
The Venezuelan band La Vida Boheme is one of the most popular new bands in all of Latin America.
Their first album, ""Nuestra,"" was nominated for two Latin Grammys.
Their new album, ""Sera,"" debuted at number one on the iTunes Latin rock and alternative charts.
A few weeks ago, I caught up with the band's lead singer Henry D'Arthenay, who spoke to us from a studio in Caracas.
HENRY D'ARTHENAY: Actually, my last name is D'Arthenay.
It's French, but my dad always says that it's the D'Arthenay from Carupano, which is a region from here in Venezuela, making it not D'Arthenay, but D'Arthenay.
It makes me think of The Three Musketeers, d'Artagnan.
D'ARTHENAY: Yes.
They used to call me d'Artagnan in school.
Esquire magazine compared La Vida Boheme to The Clash, thanks to their brash style, their head-on challenges to social stratification.
La Vida Boheme's new album is filled with songs about Venezuela.
And this new song called ""Cementerio Del Este"" translates literally as ""Cemetery of the East."" It touches upon the class divide that exists in the country.
D'ARTHENAY: We have two main cemeteries: the east side cemetery and the south side cemetery.
And the east side cemetery now, a lot of people like middle class and upper middle-class people are buried in the Cementerio Del Este.
South side cemetery is now very crowded.
And the worst part of it is that south side cemetery, it's beautiful.
It's one of the most beautiful places in Caracas, and it's left to ruin.
And the fact that the deceased are also divided by class (unintelligible), which I always found, you know, awful.
Yeah.
You know, the whole panorama makes me think of when you drive into New York City, for example, from JFK airport.
You're going through an enormous cemetery.
And then I'm thinking about the terrain of your music.
You've got this song, ""Cementerio Del Este."" It starts off with this slow chorus of voices.
And then it kind of turns into this '80s new-wave dance tune.
And I was thinking that it reminded me a lot of the '80s band Joy Division and Ian Curtis.
D'ARTHENAY: Yes.

And, you know, this whole idea of starting with a very simple thing, you know, with (unintelligible), which is how the song starts with the voices, and, you know, suddenly entering this like a new-wave thing for me was also like a metaphor, you know, how something so very pure like progress can be very swift, can be very, you know, like elegant, but at the same time it devours things.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""CEMENTERIO DEL ESTE"")

You know, I wanted to ask you, since you are in Caracas and your family's been there for generations, this is a country that, you know, here in this country, the U.S., we really think of Venezuela for its political chaos.
And you could say that that has occurred long before the death of President Hugo Chavez.
One of the songs on this album, ""El Mito del Progreso,"" translates to the ""Myth of Progress.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""EL MITO DEL PROGRESO"")
We hear this loud drumming and what sound like TV ads, which talk about the glory of Venezuela, channels being changed.
It really captures, I think, a sense of chaos.
D'ARTHENAY: Yeah.
I think the ""Myth of Progress,"" it speaks for itself, the title, you know?
Sometimes moving forward is not necessarily evolution.
And I feel, in a way, that we forgot that we were supposed to move forward as a country.
In some way, I sometimes feel like we haven't moved forward.
I think we're living, like a Mexican friend of mine would say, la pausa, the pause.
It's like you never get resolution.
It's just still.
(SOUNDBITE OF SONG, ""EL MITO DEL PROGRESO"")
